captions.text: Good morning, John.

Uh, he internet, is pretty great. It's weird
and economically and culturally diverse. It's

my hobby and it's my job and it's my passion
- and it's my friend.

A lot of the marvelous, weirdness and diversity
of the internet was and is because of a concept

called Net Neutrality. Basically the idea
that all the information flowing through the

pipes of the internet has to be treated the
same way, which is kind of a new thing.

Other information distribution systems never
really had that rule which allowed for people

who had money to come in and control everything.
But, with the internet, whether you're watching,

like, the most popular television show on
T.V. right now, or you're just watching me

in my office, talking to the camera and being
a weirdo, or you're looking up net neutrality

articles on Wikipedia, all of that information
has to be treated the same.

The thing is, a lot of companies with a lot
of money, don't want it to be this way. They

would rather say, "Well, if somebody wants
to pay us to deliver their content faster,

and slow everybody else down, then sure, yeah,
we want to do that."

And some companies want to be able to pay
to speed up their content while competitors

can't afford to do that, so that they can
maintain their strangle hold on the psyche

of the American people. The people who want
the internet to remain neutral are mostly,

people. We often feel like people, just normal
people, don't actually have that much influence

on how the American government is going to
get run.

Now, with Net Neutrality, this is compounded
by the fact that both technologically and

legally complected. So, it's kinda hard to
get people on board with the regulations,

especially when pro-business people can just
say, "Big government wants to regulate the
awesomest thing ever!"

And that sounds a little scary; we don't want
the government to regulate the internet. I

don't like the idea of that! But, we're not
really talking about them regulating the internet,

we're talking about them regulating the companies
that deliver the internet.

So it's really come down to a vocal and active
group of people on the internet -- it's not

a very big group of people -- being the only
folks who are championing net neutrality.

And, honestly, I didn't have a lot of hope
that we'd actually win. Like, not a big win.

Maybe we'd force a middle course, you know?
But, look, Tom Wheeler of the FCC used to

work for the cable industry, and they hate
net neutrality.

And most individual people don't care about
net neutrality; they don't even know what

net neutrality is. And practically all of
the money being spent by lobbyists is being

spent to lobby for the destruction of net
neutrality.

And yet, here I say it, in the United States
of America, where the internet has been reclassified

as a public utility, giving the government,
finally, the power to keep the internet neutral.

And the new FCC rules guarantee,that they
will do that.
We...won. We won!

It's almost a foreign idea to me. But we won.
And it's a win against the lobbyists and against

corporate interests in a situation where there
was no reason for the government to do the

right thing, except that it was the right
thing.

The other thing is that this really came down
to party lines, like there were three democrats

voting on the FCC and two republicans. And
the republicans voted against net neutrality.

So whenever people say, "It doesn't matter,
both sides are the same side," then something

huge like this happens that would've totally
gone the other wa, if there had been a different
administration in the White House.

And it's huge! This is hugely important for
the future of the internet. It's hugely important
for the future of me.

But it was dragged out over a long time, and
it was complicated and it wasn't really sure

when it was gonna actually happen and be done
with.

So it's just not very exciting, but that's
how these things happen. And I would feel

like a bit of a grapefruit if I didn't say
thank you to all of the people who fought

and worked hard to make the government realize
that they needed to keep the internet neutral.

And also, to all of the people in the actual
government who decided to do this despite

the fact that they're gonna make a lot of
corporations angry, and we know that those
corporations have a lot of power in America.

And also, I would feel bad if i didn't just
take a little moment to celebrate and be happy

about this thing that has finally happened
after a really long time of working on it.
So, THANK YOU EVERYONE, THIS IS AWESOME! HUZZAH!!
John, I'll see you on Tuesday.

Oh look, Jimmy Carter's found his bed. Find
a job!

John: Suddenly, you're just an old man playing
a video game with extremely out of date graphics.
Hank: I'm just gonna get the coins and star.
Katherine: You are such a nugget!

Hank: This is the first time Bill Clinton
has EVER FLIRTED! Are you guys fighting over

me right now? Thank you Mario! But the princess
is in another castle.
John: Why does Toad talk like that?
Hank: That's what he sounds like.

title: WE WON! Net Neutrality and Re-Thinking Cynicism

comments.text:
This isn't a WIN win but it is a win. There's still a lot to be done and a 
lot that can go wrong. Thankfully though, this has laid he groundwork for 
the USA to actually start to get out of our lagging behind the rest of the 
world in an area that is very much ripe for us to be a leader in. We should 
also be giving Google a big pat on the back for already proving that the 
fundamental ideas behind internet being a utility helps it grow and creates 
a competitive business environment where everyone wins. Yes everyone. 
Having a healthy profitable business is not a loss even if you once had an 
outright monopoly.﻿

comments.text:
What one entity has been the biggest threat to freedom of speech, the free 
flow of ideas, and roadblock to innovation and progress throughout human 
history? Government.

What one entity has been the biggest conductor of free speech, the free 
flow of ideas, and bastion of innovation and progress in all of human 
history? The internet.

Yet giving the former more control of the latter is somehow good for a free 
society?﻿

comments.text:
You won? Won what? You won having the FCC control the internet under the 
same rules they used to control the telephone companies? Because that was 
super great wasn't it. Honestly, what has the FCC ever done that makes you 
think it's a good idea to put them in control of the internet?

The internet we have is because the FCC has not been involved, it's gotten 
faster and cheaper and better in every way and the FCC will put an end to 
that progress.

Thankfully the supreme court has already twice thrown out the FCC 
encroachment and if they remain consistent they will throw this one out too.

If you want to improve internet service you should be talking about 
eliminating the monopoly privileges held by local providers, not ruining it 
for everybody.﻿

comments.text:
the new rules are fortunate for us here, but 'the people' didn't win. the 
lobbyist fight was lost, we just happened to be on the winning side this 
time.
The service providers have a great deal of money by working the system and 
buying regulators and politicians and because this is done in a dull, 
legislative way they routinely bypass the public desire for the industry to 
run better. The new tricks that they pulled was an overreach and their 
mistake as they targeted the wrong people to shake down, bigger companies. 
Google, Facebook and all the content providers and managers who make the 
real money on the internet would have gotten squeezed in this change and 
they stepped in and this is why net neutrality won.

Big money lost to Bigger money as is now the american way.﻿

comments.author: timholith45

comments.text:
It hurts to see how strongly Hank feels about something he knows so little 
about. All public utilities began this way. The government puts it camels 
head under the tent for what looks like noble reasons and we get used to 
it. Eventually there will be a few government protected area-wide 
monopolies like Comcast which will then have the FCC by the balls. Cry all 
they want about being controlled, the phone companies and the electric 
companies get whatever raise they want. What are they going to do, threaten 
to go to another source? Jail the CEO and the entire board? There's no 
power as the real as the threat which customers wield through competition.
        And since when are you as customer to Netflix hurt by Comcast 
giving them the fast lane?﻿

comments.text:
No, we did not win a shit.

Net neutrality is an imaginary concept that never existed in the first 
place.

Some sites has ever been faster than others, some server have been better 
than others and some providers are better than others. 

We want to push the government in this, but we don't see to big Government 
and its regulations as China or North Korea, where internet is just a big 
private network.

Companies are not usually evil, because they depend on having happy 
clients. States, however, don't care a shit when they reach power.﻿

comments.text:
ATTENTION EVERYONE: Net Neutrality is not giving the Government control of 
the Internet. It's just making it so that all data must be treated the 
same. We do it with water and electricity and the many other things needed 
by most people to function in day to day life. Thank you.﻿
comments.author: Billy Weed

comments.text:
How can you say you won?  The 300+ pages of rules are still secret.  You do 
no know what they passed.  I like your videos, and you strike me as an 
intelligent man, so this pains me.  I'm sorry my friend, but you drank the 
Cool-aid and believe that they passed something that is what they say it is 
(which is never the case).  Why am I skeptical?  Well, among many reasons, 
this is coming from the same people that tried to create an internet kill 
switch just a few years ago; something for "times of emergency".  The 
government wants to do anything it can to get its foot in the door to 
regulating content and the availability of information.  This is the first 
step.﻿
comments.author: DrNigelRamses

comments.text:
The internet has now been changed from a title I information service to a 
title II telecommunications service (making it a utility, like the phone 
service). Now that there is a set of obscure playing rules, the FCC 
(referee) now has the ability to  stifle innovation for whatever they deem 
unreasonable or unjust. ISP's will rely heavily on the FCC's veto power 
when making major business decisions. If the government did not have the 
ability to regulate the internet for corporate interests before, they 
certainly do now. ﻿
comments.author: InspireLiberty

comments.text:
My rigidly conservative grandfather was raving about how "Obama wants to 
regulate the internet!", and how the Republicans were championing net 
neutrality. I prefer to avoid arguments, especially with family, so I 
didn't say anything. I just wonder how somebody could so religiously follow 
politics and be so blinded by such a strict ideology that he could have 
everything backwards...﻿

I was so excited when I heard the news!! For my first college 
Argumentative/Rhetorical/Research essay I wrote about why Net Neutrality 
was necessary. I got an A on the paper, and my professor even wanted me to 
submit it to be published in future textbooks! Funny side note: the issue 
was actually resolved when I was halfway done with my essay.﻿

comments.text: Net neutrality!!! :)﻿

comments.text:
Watching this self-interested wolf leading the sheep to gleefully cheer the 
government removing consumer choice, open competition and infrastructure 
development from the internet and replacing it with a central planned 
system of political handouts to whoever gives the best hand-job would be 
funny if it was not so scary. 
Congratulations everyone. Rather then ending the tit sucking by cable 
companies, which would of taken REAL grass roots political pressure, we 
just gave Google and such it's own tit to suck on that great state 
leviathan were all trapped within. So suck on everyone. Suck on corporate 
America, suck on political class, suck on you chattering court jesters and 
to hell with everyone else.﻿

Net neutrality means more government control of the internet. How can any

comments.text:
I can't wait until they remove the sole propriety rules on 
telecommunications property used in public utilities for private services. 
That and exclusive Copyright laws that can be drawn out over 100 years 
(like Disney or Fox) especially in regards to things like patents on 
otherwise very useful technology (like BP or Edison)...


I've got no beef with the companies though. Just the whack job judges who 
empowered them with such ridiculous rulings.

I find this net neutrality fine when it comes to companies choosing how 
much they want to charge for what they deliver though. In the end the 
crappy deals would go away anyway even with net neutrality if the 
monopolies were lifted.﻿
comments.author: bandrukesucks

comments.text:
"We're not really talking about them (government) regulating the internet. 
We're talking about them regulating the companies that deliver the 
internet." That is incredibly naive to believe that government will just 
leave the internet alone.  The people who the FCC and the government are 
ostensibly fighting for weren't even allowed to see the 300+ pages of 
regulations before an unelected committee ripped the internet away from the 
free market and you declare that a victory.  You are applauding the death 
knell of free speech.﻿

comments.text:
I don't comment on youtube.  I don't know why, but it's not a thing i do.  
I will say, that this video, even though it wasn't the most poignant thing 
i've read or heard in the last week, it still brought tears to my eyes. 
this is awesome and important. it's important because small voices are 
important. different opinions are important. i am the small man that exists 
nowhere in the mind of the mass media, and i am important. i am smart and 
work hard, and i am important. this is a thing that every human on this 
planet should be able to say freely. the negativity of the internet be 
damned.﻿

comments.text:
Good bye Capitalism on the internet......
This is the first of many laws that will restrict the internet. NEUTRALITY 
---> IS <--- communism. Economic neutrality.... lets give everyone a job 
and make it equal so no one makes more. Same thing as this. The internet is 
a market place so by our government doing this they are saying well you 
have a monopoly on this you can't have it anymore let us spread it around 
and make sure everyone gets some. If Jif has a monopoly on peanut butter 
but lets a say a smaller company wants more business is it fair for the 
government to say "Jif, we are not allowing you to have a monopoly on 
peanut butter anymore we have to give these other brands a chance." It is 
the same deal people. "Amazon, you own amazon prime and you have a monopoly 
on video streaming and online shopping and also have good internet speeds. 
However, (some other small company) wants in on this market so we are going 
to give you lesser internet speeds to compensate so the other companies can 
have a share.". See how it works now?????? 
Everyone gets the same speeds. Lets all be neutral.... communist...... 
neutral...... socialist....... 
If you make this internet neutral you have already socialized a capitalist 
function of 21st century living. What is stopping them from doing this to 
other things????? The constitution? Obama and his administration use that 
paper for cigars......
Capitalism, which we have in America, stands for a free market is this 
freedom? Is giving up my monopoly on a product freedom??????? The 
government should fear the people the moment the people fear the government 
we have a problem. 
My. Obama has too much power. People wake up and read the constitution 
before saying "this sounds fair". Our founding fathers were smart men who 
had it all planned out lets not tear up what has run a great nation for 200 
years.﻿
comments.author: XxoverlordxX

comments.text:
It's really irritating me that people are making this political and saying

comments.author: Bre Williamson

comments.text:
I will preface my statement by saying that I am no fan of this 
administration, but this is one thing they got right.  The only reason 
people on the Right are against this is either their big corporate doners 
told them to be, or they are just so blindly against anything Obama puts 
forth that they are against it out of principle alone.  It's not the way 
things are supposed to be!  I called into a radio talk show last week to 
try to drop some knowledge on the host and he told me that we're on the way 
to European style internet that is slower that what we have right now.  I 
tried telling him that this is going to open the door for competition like 
with Google's Fiber and AT&T UVerse's new offering of 500 Mb/Sec internet 
to compete with Google Fiber and he just wouldn't hear it.  We are so 
polarized in this country and it's going to kill us.﻿
comments.author: Cody Smiley
